<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[93, 278, 325, 293]]<|/det|>
## ADDITIONAL MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 299, 155, 313]]<|/det|>
Paper 2  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[780, 278, 904, 333]]<|/det|>
0606/23 May/June 2018 2 hours  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 339, 437, 374]]<|/det|>
Candidates answer on the Question Paper. Additional Materials: Electronic calculator  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[93, 390, 386, 406]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 416, 718, 490]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in. Write in dark blue or black pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs. Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid. DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[93, 501, 283, 515]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 515, 828, 575]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question. The use of an electronic calculator is expected, where appropriate. You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 584, 758, 628]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together. The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question. The total number of marks for this paper is 80.

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[398, 73, 598, 88]]<|/det|>
Mathematical Formulae  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[437, 165, 560, 181]]<|/det|>
## 1. ALGEBRA  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 196, 240, 212]]<|/det|>
Quadratic Equation  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 225, 382, 243]]<|/det|>
For the equation \(ax^{2} + bx + c = 0\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[420, 243, 571, 281]]<|/det|>
\[x = \frac{-b\pm\sqrt{b^{2} - 4ac}}{2a}\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 313, 228, 328]]<|/det|>
Binomial Theorem  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[242, 333, 752, 371]]<|/det|>
\[(a + b)^{n} = a^{n} + \binom{n}{1} a^{n - 1}b + \binom{n}{2} a^{n - 2}b^{2} + \ldots +\binom{n}{r} a^{n - r}b^{r} + \ldots +b^{n},\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 380, 494, 415]]<|/det|>
where \(n\) is a positive integer and \(\binom{n}{r} = \frac{n!}{(n - r)!r!}\)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[402, 481, 593, 497]]<|/det|>
## 2. TRIGONOMETRY  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 513, 156, 528]]<|/det|>
Identities  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[415, 542, 583, 610]]<|/det|>
\[\sin^{2}A + \cos^{2}A = 1\] \[\sec^{2}A = 1 + \tan^{2}A\] \[\csc^{2}A = 1 + \cot^{2}A\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 640, 241, 656]]<|/det|>
Formulae for \(\Delta ABC\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[405, 662, 590, 696]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{a}{\sin A} = \frac{b}{\sin B} = \frac{c}{\sin C}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[402, 715, 593, 770]]<|/det|>
\[a^{2} = b^{2} + c^{2} - 2bc\cos A\] \[\Delta = \frac{1}{2} bc\sin A\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 96, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 499, 90]]<|/det|>
\(A, B\) and \(C\) are subsets of the same universal set.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 104, 144, 122]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 104, 536, 121]]<|/det|>

<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[198, 135, 250, 153]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 135, 920, 153]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 228, 284, 246]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 228, 920, 246]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 351, 143, 369]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 613, 102]]<|/det|>
The variables \(x\) and \(y\) are such that \(\begin{array}{r}y = \ln (3x - 1) \end{array}\) for \(x > \frac{1}{3}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 108, 144, 127]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 73, 96, 90]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 103, 918, 136]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(x + 4\) is a factor of \(\mathrm{p}(x) = 2x^{3} + 3x^{2} + ax - 12\) . When \(\mathrm{p}(x)\) is divided by \(x - 1\) the remainder is \(b\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 151, 144, 168]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 151, 591, 168]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 151, 920, 168]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 428, 143, 446]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 428, 715, 446]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 75, 570, 103]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 94, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 918, 106]]<|/det|>
An experiment was carried out recording values of \(y\) for certain values of \(x\). The variables \(x\) and \(y\) are thought to be connected by the relationship \(y = ax^n\), where \(a\) and \(n\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 120, 144, 136]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 119, 613, 136]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 230, 918, 262]]<|/det|>
<pre>The values of \(\ln y\) and \(\ln x\) were plotted and a line of best fit drawn. This is shown in the diagram below.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[165, 291, 831, 598]]<|/det|>
<pre>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 630, 144, 649]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 630, 918, 648]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 832, 410, 850]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 832, 920, 850]]<|/det|>

<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 76, 144, 95]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 75, 801, 96]]<|/det|>
Express \(5x^{2} - 14x - 3\) in the form \(p(x + q)^{2} + r\) , where \(p\) , \(q\) and \(r\) are constants. [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 73, 106, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 918, 106]]<|/det|>
A particle moves in a straight line such that its displacement, \(s\) metres, from a fixed point \(O\) at time \(t\) seconds, is given by \(\;s = 4 + \cos 3t\),   where \(t \geqslant 0\) . The particle is initially at rest.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 120, 141, 136]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 119, 598, 136]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 119, 918, 136]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 319, 143, 337]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 318, 755, 338]]<|/det|>
Find the distance travelled by the particle between \(t = \frac{\pi}{4}\) and \(t = \frac{\pi}{2}\) seconds.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 319, 918, 338]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 645, 141, 663]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 645, 504, 663]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 645, 918, 663]]<|/det|>

In this question all lengths are in metres.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 253, 918, 317]]<|/det|>
A water container is in the shape of a triangular prism. The diagrams show the container and its cross-section. The cross-section of the water in the container is an isosceles triangle \(ABC\), with angle \(ABC =\) angle \(BAC = 30^\circ\). The length of \(AB\) is \(x\) and the depth of water is \(h\). The length of the container is 5.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 331, 144, 350]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 331, 838, 350]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 331, 918, 350]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 73, 143, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 848, 90]]<|/det|>
The container is filled at a rate of \(0.5 \mathrm{m}^3\) per minute. At the instant when \(h\) is \(0.25 \mathrm{m}\), find

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 103, 185, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 103, 450, 121]]<|/det|>
the rate at which \(h\) is increasing,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 103, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 505, 185, 523]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 505, 448, 523]]<|/det|>
the rate at which \(x\) is increasing.
